awd_titl_txt: Predictors of Successful Between-Community Cooperation in Effective Resource Management
awd_abstract_narration:
Resource management and conservation initiatives often require that communities work together to manage or conserve forests, grasslands, watersheds, and fisheries. While development partners emphasize scaling up the initiatives that work to new locations, we still understand little about when and why communities do or do not work together to manage or conserve, impeding successful scaling up and potentially leading to an inefficient use of donor dollars. This project, conducted in collaboration with a coastal community network that is funded by US Forest Service, unifies research from across academia and the development world to make concrete predictions about when and why communities work together in resource management. It will fund and train a postdoctoral researcher, a graduate student, and nine research team members in scientific research methods. The project will generate a set of guidelines for how development partners can select pilot sites where between-community cooperation is likely to succeed; with limited hurdles to cooperation, partners can then work out other obstacles to scaling up before expanding their initiatives.

This project investigates whether individuals’ concerns about what happens to neighboring communities, plus their connections with those communities, promotes successful resource management. Until now, ideas about what might promote between-community cooperation have remained largely theoretical and have usually been evaluated in the laboratory. This project involves on-the-ground data collection in 32 communities, where the project team will collect individual-level data about attitudes toward and connections with neighboring communities, as well as other candidate predictors of between-community cooperation, before the rollout of a fisheries management initiative. The team will then revisit these individuals to measure their participation in between-community cooperation 12 months after initiative rollout. By assessing the relevance of baseline factors to later successful resource management, this project provides a real-world test of theoretical work on when and why between-community cooperation works.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Sustainable resource management is a principal policy concern for the 21st century and is one of the UNDP's sustainable development goals. The end goal of sustainable management is for resources like forests and fish stocks to be available for future use, and a key concern is to get people to change their behavior in the present, like reducing how much wood or fish people take.

 

Many resource-management programs focus on community-based management: programs support local users to design and implement management programs that build on existing local leadership, institutions, and norms. These programs require the local users to work together, to benefit the entire community by protecting the resource. Work from academia, international organizations, and smaller nonprofits show that several things matter for sustainable use, like effective leadership and institutions, community participation in creating rules for how much people can take, and clearly designating who can and can’t use the resource.

 

This works well when there’s only one community involved, but many resources, like fisheries and forests are accessed by multiple communities. These basic principles do still apply – like effective leadership, working together to create rules, clear boundaries – but it can be harder to get people to work together on *anything*, including sustainable management, when more people are involved. Knowing how to better support collective action like this can potentially improve the design of initiatives meant to benefit multiple communities, whether those initiatives come from small nonprofits or even governmental or international organizations.

 

Based on our past work, we hypothesized that having more relationships that span community boundaries might improve participation in resource management. Research in anthropology, political science, psychology, conservation biology, and sociology has shown that these long-distance social relationships are often sources of (1) money, including for emergencies and for big expenditures; (2) information, including about new methods of farming or otherwise making money; and (3) trust, where knowing someone in another community means you know more about that community, including whether people there mean you harm or not. In other words, if you’re connected to people in other villages, neighborhoods, or towns, you not only know more about them, you also have outside sources of support and of information. Long-distance relationships can increase the value we place in people who live in other places.

 

Working in collaboration with a local nonprofit organization, we visited 28 fishing villages in 2022 and 2023 (Figure 1). These villages are split into five larger groups that are meant to work together on managing their fisheries – in other words, these are big fisheries accessible by multiple communities, making management harder. Our team asked 1317 people about their participation in fisheries management activities, their incomes and business activities, their social relationships, and whether they think local government is doing a good job with fisheries management.

 

First, we found support for previous findings on long-distance relationships and on sustainable management. Long-distance relationships promoted sustainable management by reducing conflict, sharing successful management strategies and opportunities for resource-based income (Pisor et al 2024), and providing large loans for new business expenses (Figure 2; Smith et al 2023). Individuals who thought local management was working better were more likely to participate in fisheries management (Smith et al 2024).

 

Second, we found that people with long-distance relationships were more likely to participate in fisheries management (Figure 3; Smith et al in press). People with more long-distance relationships were also more likely to trust other communities, which in turn also predicted greater participation – long-distance friends thus encouraged participation directly and indirectly by fostering trust. 

 

Intellectual merit. This work was the product of multiple disciplines and sectors, and is speaking back to those multiple disciplines and sectors. We have two published and one accepted paper so far, two in widely read journals: Conservation Letters and Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society: Biological Sciences. We also are working closely with our nonprofit partner to make these findings actionable, for initiatives in their organization and beyond. We’ve also brought these results to conferences of anthropologists, psychologists, and conservation biologists, with more planned in the near future.


Broader impacts. Beyond the applicability of these findings, this project has created training opportunities for five early-career researchers: one postdoc and four college graduates local to the study site – all four of whom are from a group underrepresented in the sciences. All five trainees received support and training in methods like individual interviews, focus groups, and experimental techniques that are regularly used in industry and the nonprofit sector, as well as in academia. Our project postdoc has gone on to an NIH (National Institutes of Health) funded postdoc in global health, while two of our four research assistants have gone on to complete master's degrees.
